Zimbabwe: Govt Restricts Hunting After Cecil the Lion's Death 
The move comes as the National Railways of Zimbabwe fired 350 workers while Air Zimbabwe was said to be consulting on how to fire more of its workers. 
Friday night, workers told Newzimbabwe.com that NRZ was targeting at firing 1 500 by the end of the exercise. 
Government has announced plans to cut its workforce by 50 percent as a way of cutting down the huge wage bill. 
The recent Supreme Court ruling has opened a floodgate of dismissals with top companies such as Econet Wireless and Zimasco firing a significant number of employees. 
Media groups such as Alpha Media Holdings, Associated Newspapers of Zimbabwe and the Fingaz have also followed suit. 
President Robert Mugabe recently announced that about 9000 workers have been fired so far due to the Supreme Court ruling which allowed firms to fire employees on notice without benefits. 
The trade unions have appealed to Mugabe to use his presidential powers to stop the carnage. 
But Mugabe, through his deputy Emmerson Mnangagwa, has refused to do so, saying there is a fast way to solve the crisis. Zimbabwe
